The need to rebalance creates an artificiality. Sure its real buying or selling - but a function of market structure and not natural demand/supply.

With the growth of ETFs the day's end rebalancing always exaggerates on upside and downside. I have been writing about this artificiality for four years on @realmoney This and risk parity, which allocates to changing risk - has the same impact on price discovery.

@realmoney Is This The Start of The Big Rotation Out of Growth and Into Value? * This is a very important question to be answered... * I say it might be! Ss (S&P Index) over Ns (Nasdaq Index) bigly today. (h/t @todd_harrison) If this trend continues and accelerates

, a lot of investors are going to be asking themselves over the weekend whether a big rotation out of growth and into value has commenced. I am of the view that The Big Rotation might have begun. @jimcramer @tomkeene @cnbcfastmoney @SquawkCNBC @andrewrsorkin @carlquintanilla

If at the end of the year you and I are down -11% and the S&P is -28%, neither of us would consider it a very good year! But a fund manager would think he hit a homerun! There is a distinction, @revshark.

A fund manager who has a 20% cash position may not sound bearish to you or me - but he is competing against a fully invested Index and benchmark. So 20% cash is actually a bearish position. These guys play relative performance while you and I play absolute performance.

@realmoney Nothing from nothing, but... Apr 17, 2020 | 02:17 PM EDT DOUG KASS Thin Reed Indicator * Market mavens on CNBC are predominantly negative So, over the last two days, I have summarized and recorded the market views of parading "talking heads," panelists, commentators,

strategists, etc. on CNBC. Since yesterday morning there have been 23 that have offered a market view - 19 were bearish (looking for lower stock prices) and only four were looking for higher prices. Just anecdotal, but interesting, as a measure of investor sentiment. @revshark
